# üíµ **Valuing Human Life** {background-color="#1c4982"}

## Why VSL Matters

- Significance: Policies on air quality, drinking water, and safety affect mortality risks.  
- Constraint: Life is priceless, but resources are scarce ‚Üí trade-offs are unavoidable.  
- Core Question: How much should society pay for small reductions in mortality risk?



## ‚öñÔ∏è Economic Approach

- We do not price a life; we value small risk changes.  
- Value of Reduced Mortality Risk  
  - Individual WTP for a small change in death risk.  
  - MRS between money and risk.  
  - Aggregated to the Value of a Statistical Life (VSL) = $ per one expected death avoided.

::: callout-note
Rule of thumb: VSL is an average WTP-based measure; it is not what any one person‚Äôs life ‚Äúis worth.‚Äù
:::



## üí° CV Example ‚Üí VSL

Air Quality Policy  
- Cost = $500M, deaths reduced by 50/year.  
- If 100M households each WTP $10/year:

$$
\text{Total WTP} = 100{,}000{,}000 \times 10 = $1\text{B}, \quad
\text{VSL} = \frac{$1\text{B}}{50} = $20\text{M per death}
$$

::: {.fragment}
Interpretation: Society implicitly values one avoided statistical death at $20M in this context.
:::



## üíº Wage‚ÄìRisk Approach

- Observe wage premia for riskier jobs (loggers, pilots, fishers), controlling for skills and job traits.  
- Assumptions: workers know risks and have choice across jobs.

Back-of-the-envelope  
- Extra pay = $700/year, excess fatal risk = 1/10,000  
$$
\text{VSL} = \frac{700}{1/10{,}000} = $7{,}000{,}000
$$

::: callout-note
Caveats: Selection into risky jobs, limited options, risk perception, male-dominated samples ‚Üí external validity concerns.
:::



## üìä Meta-Study Benchmarks

| Study | Scope | Mean VSL (USD, $M) | Notes |
|:--|:--|:--:|:--|
| Viscusi (1996) | U.S. wage-risk | ~5.0 (1986 $) | Early synthesis |
| Doucouliagos et al. (2009) | 32 studies | 8.4 (SD 7.9) | Wide range |
| Lindhjem et al. (2018) | 68 studies | 8.1‚Äì11.4 | Recent meta |

::: {.fragment}
Pattern: VSL rises with income and over time (inflation + real income growth).
:::

## üß† Age & Risk Context

- Inverted U-shape in age‚ÄìVSL (e.g., Viscusi 2008):  
  - 18‚Äì24 ‚âà $3.7M ‚Üí 35‚Äì44 peak ‚âà $9.7M ‚Üí 55‚Äì62 ‚âà $3.4M.  
- Risk type matters: Cancer risks often valued higher than accident risks.  
- Policy practice: Proposals for ‚Äúcancer differential‚Äù (higher VSL for carcinogens).

## üß© Applications

- Environmental rules: Mortality benefits dominate CBAs  
  - Clean Air Act (US): >90% of total benefits from mortality risk reductions.  
  - EU Clean Air Package: ~70%.  
- Climate: Heat-related deaths (‚âà 9,700/year in US) ‚Üí influences SCC.  
- Transport: Airbags, roof strength, speed design.  
- Public Health: Pandemic policy appraisal (NPIs, vaccination).



## ü¶† COVID-19 Illustration

- Using VSL ‚âà $10M ‚Üí social distancing benefits estimated in trillions (US).  
- 1918 flu evidence: Early interventions ‚Üí lower mortality & better recovery.  
- Lesson: Public-health measures can be ethically right and economically efficient.



## üê¶ Ecosystem Services Case: Vultures (India)

- Keystone scavengers nearly collapsed (1990s) due to diclofenac in cattle.  
- Result: Carcass decay ‚Üí disease spread ‚Üí ‚âà 100,000 extra deaths/year (2000‚Äì2005).  
- With India-adjusted VSL, mortality damages ‚âà $69.4B/year.  
- Insight: Biodiversity loss can be valued via human mortality, strengthening conservation CBAs.



## üß≠ Ethics: Critique vs. Defense

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
###### Critiques
- Life is priceless; monetization is offensive.  
- Rights-based view: deaths from pollution are not tradable.  
- Excludes vulnerable voices; WTP reflects ability to pay.
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
###### Defenses
- Scarcity: ignoring benefits is itself immoral.  
- CBA = transparent prioritization (more lives per $).  
- Society already trades off risk vs. money daily.
:::
::::



## üßÆ Classroom Q&A: Quick VSL Calc

Scenario 1 (Wage‚Äìrisk): Police premium $700/year; extra risk 1/10,000  
$$
\text{VSL}=\frac{700}{1/10{,}000}=$7{,}000{,}000
$$

Scenario 2 (Policy WTP):  
- Risk falls from 1/100{,}000 ‚Üí 1/150{,}000 for 1,000,000 people  
- Expected deaths: 10 ‚Üí 6.67 (‚Üì 3.33)  
- WTP per person = $5 ‚Üí Total WTP = $5M  
$$
\text{VSL}=\frac{$5\text{M}}{3.33}\approx $1.5\text{M}
\quad\text{or}\quad
\text{VSL}=\frac{$5}{(1/150{,}000-1/100{,}000)}
$$

1. Should VSL vary by age, income, or risk type?

## üìå Takeaways

- VSL = WTP-based value for small mortality risk changes.  
- Estimates vary by income, age, context, and politics.  
- Used across environmental, transport, and health policies.  
- Goal is not to price life, but to allocate scarce resources to save more life-years effectively.
